tasks.title: Unit tests for API key generator
tasks.context: Create backend/src/utils/__tests__/api-key-generator.test.ts — unit tests for backend/src/utils/api-key-generator.ts (110 lines). This file exports: API_KEY_PREFIX = 'inv_live_', TEST_KEY_PREFIX = 'inv_test_', generateApiKey(isTest?: boolean): GeneratedApiKey — returns { key: string, hash: string } where key starts with 'inv_live_' (default) or 'inv_test_' (when isTest=true), key contains 64 hex chars after prefix (from randomBytes(32)), hash is SHA256 hex of the full key. Also exports hashApiKey(key: string): string — returns SHA256 hex digest, throws TypeError for empty string. Also exports isTestKey(key: string): boolean — returns true if key starts with 'inv_test_'. Write exactly 5 tests: (1) generateApiKey() returns key starting with 'inv_live_' and hash is a 64-char hex string, (2) generateApiKey(true) returns key starting with 'inv_test_', (3) hashApiKey returns consistent hash — hashApiKey('test') === hashApiKey('test'), (4) hashApiKey throws TypeError for empty string, (5) isTestKey returns true for 'inv_test_xxx' and false for 'inv_live_xxx'. Use describe/it blocks, import { generateApiKey, hashApiKey, isTestKey, API_KEY_PREFIX, TEST_KEY_PREFIX } from '../api-key-generator'. Max 35 lines. No mocking needed — crypto functions work in Node test environment.

strengths: All 5 required tests implemented exactly as specified
Proper imports of all required functions and constants
Correct use of describe/it blocks for test structure
Appropriate assertions for key format validation (prefix, length, hex pattern)
Tests both live and test key generation paths
Validates hash consistency and format correctly
Proper error testing with TypeError expectation
Tests boolean logic for isTestKey function
Clean, readable test code under 35 lines as required
No unnecessary mocking or complexity
Follows TypeScript best practices with proper typing
Covers all specified behaviors for generateApiKey, hashApiKey, and isTestKey
Validates prefixes, key lengths, and hash formats with regex
Tests error throwing for invalid input
Imports constants correctly and stays within the line limit

tasks.title: Unit tests for webhook signature utility
tasks.context: Create backend/src/utils/__tests__/webhook-signature.test.ts — unit tests for backend/src/utils/webhook-signature.ts (46 lines). This file exports: SIGNATURE_HEADER = 'x-invoica-signature', generateSignature(payload: string, secret: string): string — returns 'sha256=' + HMAC-SHA256 hex digest, verifySignature(payload: string, secret: string, signature: string): boolean — returns true if signature matches using timing-safe comparison, returns false for length mismatch, generateWebhookSecret(): string — returns 'whsec_' + 48 hex chars (randomBytes(24)). Write exactly 5 tests: (1) generateSignature returns string starting with 'sha256=', (2) generateSignature is deterministic — same payload+secret produces same signature, (3) verifySignature returns true for valid signature (generate then verify with same payload+secret), (4) verifySignature returns false for wrong secret, (5) generateWebhookSecret returns string starting with 'whsec_' and has length 54 (6 prefix + 48 hex). Use describe/it blocks, import { SIGNATURE_HEADER, generateSignature, verifySignature, generateWebhookSecret } from '../webhook-signature'. Max 35 lines.

issues.description: Could add edge case tests for empty payload/secret, but not required by spec

strengths: Exactly 5 tests as specified in task requirements
Proper imports matching the expected exports
Clean describe/it structure with descriptive test names
Correct regex patterns for signature and secret validation
Good test data with realistic JSON payload
Proper deterministic testing approach
Tests cover all exported functions including SIGNATURE_HEADER constant
File length (30 lines) well under the 35 line limit
No code fences or invalid syntax
Tests validate exact format requirements (sha256= prefix, whsec_ prefix, lengths)
Covers all specified scenarios with concise, readable tests
Uses regex-based matching for signature and secret formats
Ensures deterministic signature generation and proper verification
Checks both valid and invalid secret cases
Respects max line count and uses standard Jest structure

tasks.title: Unit tests for logger utility
tasks.context: Create backend/src/utils/__tests__/logger.test.ts — unit tests for backend/src/utils/logger.ts (113 lines). This file exports: logger object with methods info, warn, error, debug. Each method calls console.log/warn/error/debug respectively with a formatted message. In non-production mode (NODE_ENV !== 'production'), format is '[timestamp] LEVEL: message {meta}'. In production mode, format is JSON string with timestamp, level, message, and meta fields. Write exactly 5 tests: (1) logger.info calls console.log — spy on console.log, call logger.info('test'), expect console.log to have been called, (2) logger.error calls console.error — spy on console.error, call logger.error('err'), expect called, (3) logger.warn calls console.warn — spy on console.warn, call logger.warn('w'), expect called, (4) logger.debug calls console.debug — spy on console.debug, call logger.debug('d'), expect called, (5) logger.info includes message in output — spy on console.log, call logger.info('hello world'), expect console.log to have been called with string containing 'hello world'. Use jest.spyOn and restore in afterEach. import { logger } from '../logger'. Max 35 lines.

issues.description: Could add explicit type annotations for spies, though TypeScript inference handles this correctly

strengths: Exactly 5 tests as specified in task requirements
Proper use of jest.spyOn with mockImplementation to prevent actual console output
Correct afterEach cleanup with jest.restoreAllMocks()
Clean test descriptions that match the task spec exactly
Appropriate use of expect.stringContaining for message validation
Concise implementation at 32 lines (under 35 line limit)
No code fences or invalid syntax
Follows Jest best practices with describe/it structure
Proper import statement using relative path
Covers all four logger methods plus a content assertion
Uses jest.spyOn and cleanup via jest.restoreAllMocks
Import path and test structure match project conventions
Test count and line count align with task requirements

tasks.title: Unit tests for graceful shutdown utility
tasks.context: Create backend/src/utils/__tests__/graceful-shutdown.test.ts — unit tests for backend/src/utils/graceful-shutdown.ts (58 lines). This file exports: DEFAULT_CONFIG = { timeout: 10000, signals: ['SIGTERM', 'SIGINT'] }, createShutdownHandler(server, config?): () => Promise<void> — takes a server object with close(cb) method, returns an async shutdown function. When shutdown is called: sets isShuttingDown=true (prevents double-shutdown), calls onShutdown if provided, calls server.close(), logs to console. Write exactly 5 tests: (1) DEFAULT_CONFIG has timeout=10000 and signals array with SIGTERM and SIGINT, (2) createShutdownHandler returns a function, (3) calling shutdown function calls server.close — create mock server { close: jest.fn((cb) => cb()) }, create handler, call it, expect server.close to have been called, (4) double shutdown is prevented — create handler, call twice, server.close should only be called once, (5) onShutdown callback is called — create handler with onShutdown: jest.fn(), call shutdown, expect onShutdown to have been called. Use describe/it, import { DEFAULT_CONFIG, createShutdownHandler } from '../graceful-shutdown'. Max 40 lines. Mock console.log in beforeEach to suppress output.

issues.description: Could add explicit check for signals array length to ensure it contains exactly SIGTERM and SIGINT

strengths: All 5 required tests implemented correctly
Proper console.log mocking in beforeEach/afterEach
Clean test structure with describe/it blocks
Correct imports from relative path
Proper async/await usage in shutdown tests
Mock server implementation matches specification exactly
Double shutdown prevention test correctly validates behavior
onShutdown callback test properly configured with config object
File length within 40-line requirement (39 lines)
No code fences or invalid syntax
Covers all specified behaviors of DEFAULT_CONFIG and createShutdownHandler
Prevents double invocation of server.close as required
Mocks console.log in beforeEach/afterEach to keep test output clean
Uses Jest async/await patterns correctly
No markdown code fences present in the source file

tasks.title: Unit tests for API key validator schemas
tasks.context: Create backend/src/validators/__tests__/api-key-schemas.test.ts — unit tests for backend/src/validators/api-key-schemas.ts (77 lines). This file exports 3 Zod schemas: createApiKeySchema (name: string min 1 max 100, expiresInDays: positive int max 365 optional, scopes: array of enum ['invoices:read','invoices:write','settlements:read','webhooks:manage','api-keys:manage'] optional default []), apiKeyQuerySchema (limit: coerce int 1-100 default 10, offset: coerce int min 0 default 0, status: enum ['active','revoked','expired'] optional), rotateApiKeySchema (expiresInDays: positive int max 365 optional). Write exactly 5 tests: (1) createApiKeySchema accepts valid {name:'My Key'} and scopes defaults to empty array, (2) createApiKeySchema rejects empty name — parse({name:''}) throws, (3) apiKeyQuerySchema applies defaults — parse({}).limit === 10 and parse({}).offset === 0, (4) apiKeyQuerySchema rejects limit over 100 — parse({limit:101}) throws, (5) rotateApiKeySchema rejects expiresInDays over 365 — parse({expiresInDays:366}) throws. Use describe/it, import { createApiKeySchema, apiKeyQuerySchema, rotateApiKeySchema } from '../api-key-schemas'. Max 35 lines.

strengths: All 5 required tests implemented exactly as specified
Proper test structure with describe/it blocks
Correct imports from relative path
Tests cover both positive and negative validation cases
Concise implementation at 22 lines (well under 35 line limit)
No unnecessary abstractions or extra functionality
Proper Jest expectations with specific assertions
Tests validate default behavior and boundary conditions
Tests align precisely with the spec requirements
Concise and within the 35-line limit
Covers both default-value and error scenarios as requested

tasks.title: Dashboard settings page
tasks.context: Create frontend/app/dashboard/settings/page.tsx — a dashboard settings page as a React server component. This page should display account configuration options. Structure: export default function DashboardSettingsPage(). Return a div with: (1) h1 'Settings' with text-2xl font-bold mb-6, (2) Two sections each in a bg-white rounded-lg shadow p-6 mb-6: Section 1 'General' — h2 with text-lg font-semibold mb-4, then a form-like div with 3 rows each as flex items-center justify-between py-3 border-b: row 1 label 'Company Name' with span 'Acme Corp' and an Edit button (text-blue-600), row 2 label 'Time Zone' with span 'UTC', row 3 label 'Default Currency' with span 'USD'. Section 2 'Notifications' — h2 with text-lg font-semibold mb-4, then 3 rows: row 1 label 'Email Alerts' with a green 'Enabled' badge (bg-green-100 text-green-800 px-2 py-1 rounded-full text-xs), row 2 label 'Webhook Failures' with green 'Enabled' badge, row 3 label 'Monthly Reports' with gray 'Disabled' badge (bg-gray-100 text-gray-600). Use 'use client' directive. Max 55 lines. Tailwind CSS only.

tasks.title: Dashboard usage page
